title: النِّدَاءُ الْمُتَقَدِّمُ
description: Learn advanced vocative rules: calling nouns with أل (يا أيها), calling nouns annexed to ياء المتكلم (يا ربّ), and vocative of lamentation with annexed nouns.

notes.title: Review: Basic Vocative
content: The vocative (النداء) is used to call someone's attention. The basic structure is: vocative particle (يَا، أَيَا، هَيَا، أَيْ، أَ) + the called noun (المُنَادَى). The case of المُنَادَى depends on its type.

Types: 1) مُفْرَد عَلَم (single proper noun) = مَبْنِيّ عَلَى الضَّمّ, 2) نَكِرَة مَقْصُودَة (intended indefinite) = مَبْنِيّ عَلَى الضَّمّ, 3) مُضَاف (annexed), نَكِرَة غَيْر مَقْصُودَة (unintended indefinite), شَبِيه بِالْمُضَاف = مَنْصُوب.
keyPoints: مفرد علم، نكرة مقصودة: مبني على الضم
مُضَاف، نكرة غير مقصودة، شبيه بالمضاف: منصوب
Advanced forms build on these basics

examples.english: O Muhammad! (proper noun - built on ضَمّ)
O man! (intended indefinite - built on ضَمّ)
O Abdullah! (annexed - منصوب)
O one climbing a mountain! (resembling annexed - منصوب)

notes.title: Calling Nouns with أل (نداء ما فيه أل)
content: In Arabic, يَا cannot directly precede a noun with the definite article أل. Instead, أَيُّهَا (for masculine) or أَيَّتُهَا (for feminine) is inserted as a واسطة (intermediary): يَا أَيُّهَا الرَّجُلُ، يَا أَيَّتُهَا الْمَرْأَةُ.
The structure is: يَا + أَيُّ/أَيَّة (مُنَادَى مَبْنِيّ عَلَى الضَّمّ) + هَا (للتنبيه) + الاسم المحلى بأل (بَدَل or صِفَة). The noun with أل is either بَدَل مَرْفُوع or صِفَة مَرْفُوعَة.
keyPoints: الاسم بأل: بَدَل أو صِفَة مَرْفُوعَة

examples.english: O mankind! (Quran - النَّاسُ = بدل)
O you who believe! (Quran)
O tranquil soul! (Quran 89:27)
O Messenger, convey! (Quran 5:67)

notes.title: Calling Nouns Annexed to ياء المتكلم
content: When calling a noun annexed to ياء المتكلم (my), there are several options. For يَا رَبِّ (my Lord), the most common forms are: 1) يَا رَبِّ (with كَسْرَة, ياء deleted), 2) يَا رَبِّي (with ياء ساكنة), 3) يَا رَبَّ (with فَتْحَة).

This applies to other nouns too: يَا أَبِي/يَا أَبَتِ/يَا أَبَتَا (O my father), يَا أُمِّي/يَا أُمَّتِ (O my mother). The تَاء in أَبَتِ/أُمَّتِ is تَاء التَّأْنِيث used for التَّرَحُّم (compassion/tenderness).
keyPoints: يَا رَبِّ: ياء deleted, shown by كَسْرَة

examples.english: My Lord, forgive me (ياء deleted)
O my Lord, have mercy on me (ياء retained)

examples.arabic: يَا أَبَتِ لِمَ تَعْبُدُ مَا لَا يَسْمَعُ
examples.english: O my father, why do you worship what cannot hear? (Quran 19:42)
O my son, do not associate partners with Allah (Quran 31:13)

notes.title: The Vocative of Lamentation (نداء المندوب)
content: نِدَاءُ الْمَنْدُوبِ is used to express grief or lamentation over someone or something. It uses وَا (instead of يَا) and ends with an extended أَلِف: وَازَيْدَاهُ، وَامُحَمَّدَاهُ.
The extended endings can be: أَلِف + هَاء (وَازَيْدَاهْ) or أَلِف alone (وَازَيْدَا). For annexed nouns (مُنَادَى مُضَاف), the أَلِف attaches to the end of the construct.
keyPoints: Expresses grief: وَازَيْدَاهُ = Alas for Zayd!
For مضاف: extend after complete construct

examples.english: Alas for Zayd! (single noun lamentation)
Alas for the Commander of the Faithful! (annexed)
Alas, my head! (expressing pain)
Alas, what a calamity!

notes.title: Special Cases in Vocative
content: Several special cases exist in the vocative. للهُمَّ is a special form of يَا اللهُ with the مِيم replacing يَا. يَا ابْنَ أُمِّ and يَا ابْنَ عَمِّ have special contraction patterns.
The vocative can also express تَعَجُّب (astonishment): يَا لَلْعَجَبِ (what wonder!), يَا لَلْمُصِيبَةِ (what a calamity!). Here لَ is لَام التَّعَجُّب.

examples.english: O Allah, forgive me (اللهُمَّ = يَا اللهُ)

examples.arabic: يَا ابْنَ أُمَّ لَا تَأْخُذْ بِلِحْيَتِي
examples.english: O son of my mother, do not seize my beard (Quran 20:94)
What wonder at this!
O Allah! [help] the oppressed (seeking divine aid)

notes.title: Deleting the Vocative Particle
content: The vocative particle (يَا) can be omitted when context is clear. This is common in Quranic Arabic and eloquent speech. The مُنَادَى retains its case/form even without the particle.
Examples from Quran: رَبِّ اغْفِرْ لِي (يَا omitted), يُوسُفُ أَعْرِضْ عَنْ هَذَا (O Yusuf, turn away from this). The understood يَا is in تَقْدِير.
keyPoints: يَا can be omitted if context is clear
Common in Quran: رَبِّ (= يَا رَبِّ)

examples.english: My Lord, grant me wisdom (Quran 26:83) - يَا omitted
Yusuf, turn away from this (Quran 12:29)
Our Lord, give us good in this world (Quran 2:201)
O Noah, he is not of your family (Quran 11:46)

exercises.prompt: لَا يَجُوزُ أَنْ تَدْخُلَ يَا عَلَى الاِسْمِ الْمُحَلَّى بِأَلْ مُبَاشَرَةً، فَنَقُولُ: يَا _____ الرَّجُلُ
exercises.promptEn: يَا cannot directly enter on a noun with أل, so we say: يَا _____ الرَّجُلُ

exercises.prompt: فِي نِدَاءِ الْمُضَافِ إِلَى يَاءِ الْمُتَكَلِّمِ، يَجُوزُ حَذْفُ الْيَاءِ مَعَ بَقَاءِ _____، مِثْلَ: يَا رَبِّ
exercises.promptEn: In calling nouns annexed to ياء المتكلم, the ياء may be deleted while keeping the _____, like: يَا رَبِّ

exercises.prompt: حَرْفُ النِّدَاءِ لِلتَّفَجُّعِ وَالتَّحَسُّرِ هُوَ _____، مِثْلَ: وَازَيْدَاهُ
exercises.promptEn: The vocative particle for lamentation and grief is _____, like: وَازَيْدَاهُ

exercises.prompt: يَا أَبَتِ - التَّاءُ هُنَا تَاءُ التَّأْنِيثِ لِلتَّرَحُّمِ، وَأَصْلُهَا يَا _____
exercises.promptEn: يَا أَبَتِ - the تَاء here is the feminine تَاء for tenderness, originally يَا _____

exercises.prompt: اللَّهُمَّ صِيغَةٌ خَاصَّةٌ، وَالْمِيمُ فِيهَا _____ عَنْ يَا
exercises.promptEn: اللَّهُمَّ is a special form, and the مِيم in it _____ for يَا

exercises.prompt: يَا أَيُّهَا النَّاسُ - كَلِمَةُ النَّاسُ إِعْرَابُهَا _____ مَرْفُوعٌ أَوْ نَعْتٌ مَرْفُوعٌ
exercises.promptEn: يَا أَيُّهَا النَّاسُ - the word النَّاسُ is parsed as _____ in nominative or an adjective

exercises.answer: O you... (vocative intermediary for nouns with أل, masculine)
The called noun in lamentation (expressing grief)

exercises.prompt: The intermediary used before nouns with أل in vocative (feminine)
The special vocative form meaning 'O Allah' with مِيم instead of يَا
The vocative particle used for lamentation and expressing grief
